default.description: Default text refers to the main or prominent textual content. Suitable for important headlines, titles, or primary information that requires the most attention.

inverse.description: Inverse text refers to the opposite color that contrasts with the background.

secondary.description: Secondary text is for supporting or supplementary information. Often used for descriptions, labels, captions, or any content that is less significant than the default text but still relevant to the user experience.

emphasis.description: Emphasized text refers to a styling technique used to give importance to a specific text. Often used to draw attention to key points, important information, or to differentiate specific content from the rest of the text.

links.description: Links refers to emphasis clickable elements.

visited.description: Visited link" refers to a hyperlink that has been previously clicked or accessed.

disabled.description: Disabled text refers to a particular element is temporarily or permanently disabled and cannot be accessed or interacted with.

success-moderate.description: Success text refers to content that signifies a positive or affirmative message.

info-moderate.description: Info text gives a clear summary of the information.

warning-moderate.description: Warning text refers to content that conveys a warning, caution, or alert.

error-moderate.description: Error text refers to incorrect or invalid information on a form or during a data entry process.

success-weak.description: Success text refers to content that signifies a positive or affirmative message.

weak.description: Weak border refers to a subtle border style.

moderate.description: The default border is the standard border style. It strikes a balance between visibility and subtlety, providing a noticeable border around the element without overpowering the overall design. Suitable for solid separator.

strong.description: Strong default border refers to a standard border style that is more pronounced and visually prominent than a moderate border. Suitable for dotted separators.

extreme.description: Extreme default border refers to a standard border style that is branded.

enabled.description: Border on normal state refers to the default appearance and behavior of a clickable element. It represents the initial or resting state, typically before any user interaction has occurred.

muted.description: Muted border indicates that the ui element is not editable and is intended for viewing purposes only. Suitable for read-only UI controls.

transparent.description: Transparent border is intented to create a subtle and understated appearance. Suitable for the less important ui control.

hover.description: Border on hover state refers to an interaction that the ui element is clickable. It's primarily used in desktop or laptop interfaces where cursor-based interactions are prevalent.

pressed.description: Border with pressed state is a stemporary visual alteration that provides immediate feedback to the user, confirming that their input has been recognized.

focused.description: Border on focused state refers to an interaction that occurs when the ui element is focused through keyboard navigation or other assistive technologies.

border-transparent.description: Transparent border is intented to create a subtle and understated appearance. Suitable for the less important ui control.

border-hover.description: Border on hover state refers to an interaction that the ui element is clickable. It's primarily used in desktop or laptop interfaces where cursor-based interactions are prevalent.

border-focused.description: Border on focused state refers to an interaction that occurs when the ui element is focused through keyboard navigation or other assistive technologies.

border-pressed.description: Border with pressed state is a stemporary visual alteration that provides immediate feedback to the user, confirming that their input has been recognized.

border-selected.description: Border with a moderate selected state refers to an interaction that occurs when the ui element is active.

border-selected:hover.description: Border hovering over a moderate selected state refers to an interaction that occurs when the ui element is hovered on a current selection. It's primarily used in desktop or laptop interfaces where cursor-based interactions are prevalent.

border-disabled.description: A border with a disabled state indicates that a particular function, feature, or control is currently disabled or unavailable.

border-error.description: Destructive border on normal state serves as a prominent reminder or warning, helping prevent accidental or unintended actions that could have negative implications.

text-default.description: Default text refers to the main or prominent textual content. Suitable for important headlines, titles, or primary information that requires the most attention.

text-inverse.description: Inverse text refers to the opposite color that contrasts with the background.

text-secondary.description: Secondary text is for supporting or supplementary information. Often used for descriptions, labels, captions, or any content that is less significant than the default text but still relevant to the user experience.

text-emphasis.description: Emphasized text refers to a styling technique used to give importance to a specific text. Often used to draw attention to key points, important information, or to differentiate specific content from the rest of the text.

text-disabled.description: Disabled text refers to a particular element is temporarily or permanently disabled and cannot be accessed or interacted with.
